Author: Amazing_Ad_6045

Comment: Those photos have been going around for maybe a week or two. It's not particularly relevant at the moment. The media's been reporting it but you also have to remember that among the trade war, intelligence leaks, and 500 other things happening every day, there's only so much room in the media hopper for complex immigration stories.  More importantly, the question right now in the courts and under the prior SCOTUS decision has nothing to do with whether he's associated with MS13. Any consideration of his alleged association is out scope of the current SCOTUS decision related to this case. The standing issue is that he's been deprived of due process and should be returned to receive due process for any accusations against him, as anyone and everyone protected under our constitution and under our immigration laws should receive, both noncitizens and citizens alike.  I would also add that if he is so unequivocally connected to MS13 as is alleged, the gov't should've been able to produce clear cut evidence to that effect long before we got this far and trying to interpret someone's tattoos is far from any kind of real evidence. They failed to do that on multiple occasions over several weeks in front of the courts and out of nowhere released photos of his tattoos in social media -- photos that had not been presented in court. Every indication is that their accusations against Abrego Garcia are flimsy at best.  But again, that's not relevant right now or even up for debate in the courts. The court orders are specifically focused on making sure he receives due process. If, in that due process, he is found to be guilty of something, then so be it. But he is protected under our constitution to receive that due process.

Author: Choice_Reindeer7759

Comment: Better, thanks. Much as the White House is claiming that those tattoos translate to MS13, at least some experts disagree with that claim:  Marijuana leaves, crosses and skulls are widely used as tattoos by people who do not belong to gangs. Gang crime experts said they did not stand out to them as MS-13 markers.  "I don’t believe a ‘dangerous individual’ would have such anodyne and farcically generic tattoos on his hand," said Liliana Castañeda Rossmann, a California State University San Marcos emerita professor of communication and author of the book "Transcending Gangs: Latinas Story Their Experience."  Sean Kennedy, a former federal public defender in California and now a Loyola Law School professor, said that in his experience representing and interacting with current and former MS-13 members, "The tattoos in the photo don't look familiar to me."  In fact, Kennedy said, such designs are out of character with typical MS-13 tattoos.  "Within MS-13 culture, such markings would likely be frowned upon and even viewed as a sign of cowardice, as they could be interpreted as an attempt to hide or downplay gang affiliation," Kennedy said. "That type of concealment goes against the gang's norms, which often demand bold, visible demonstrations of identity and loyalty."  Charles Katz, director of Arizona State University’s Center for Violence Prevention and Community Safety, concurred.  While Katz said that local law enforcement would be more familiar with specific tattoo designs in a given region, "I have worked on issues related to MS-13 for the past 15 years in El Salvador and the U.S. and I have never seen tattoos or graffiti suggesting that these particular tattoos are associated with MS-13".  [https://www.politifact.com/article/2025/apr/22/abrego-garcia-finger-tattoos-trump/](https://www.politifact.com/article/2025/apr/22/abrego-garcia-finger-tattoos-trump/)
